Drums of Defiance: Maroon Music from the Earliest Free Black Communities of Jamaica 


Product Description 

Featuring complex, West African influenced drumming and dancing, 
this little-known rural tradition is at the heart of modern, 
politically charged reggae music. The conviction heard here reveals 
a long history of struggle. During the 17th and 18th centuries, 
some of the Africans brought to Jamaica as slaves escaped to the 
mountains. There they settled, and over time, became known as "Maroons." 
Today, four major Maroon colonies still exist in Jamaica's rugged 
western Cockpit Country and in the eastern Blue Mountains. Some 
selections on this recording were previously issued in 1981 on 
Folkways 4027. "..an aural kaleidoscope, presenting small glimpses 
into the colorful world of the Maroon music of Jamaica." ÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¯Ã‚Â¿Ã‚Â½ÃƒÂ¯Ã‚Â¿Ã‚Â½Sing Out
